title: What would happen if everyone stopped eating meat tomorrow? - Carolyn Beans

multiple-choice.question: What happens to greenhouse gas emissions if a wizard were to suddenly appear and make all meat disappear from the world?
What would happen to the demand for fruits, vegetables, and legumes if all meat were suddenly removed from the world?

options.label: A
options.text: The demand would decrease, causing prices to drop

options.label: B
options.text: The demand would increase, causing prices to soar

options.label: C
options.text: The demand would remain the same, with no change in prices

options.label: D
options.text: The demand would decrease, causing prices to increase

multiple-choice.question: What would be the effect on the environment if all meat were suddenly removed from the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Global biodiversity would decrease, and habitat loss would increase

options.label: B
options.text: Global biodiversity would rise, and habitat loss would subside

options.label: C
options.text: There would be no change in the environment

options.label: D
options.text: The environment would remain the same, with no benefits or drawbacks

multiple-choice.question: What would happen to the health of humans if all meat were suddenly removed from the world?

options.label: A
options.text: Millions of deaths would be avoided every year, thanks to lower rates of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated with red meat consumption

options.label: B
options.text: Millions of deaths would occur every year, thanks to higher rates of heart disease, cancer, and other conditions associated with red meat consumption

options.label: C
options.text: There would be no change in the health of humans

options.label: D
options.text: The health of humans would remain the same, with no benefits and drawbacks

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why cattle are the biggest culprit in terms of greenhouse gas emissions?

options.label: A
options.text: Because they are the largest source of food for humans

options.label: B
options.text: Because they produce the most greenhouse gases per pound of meat

options.label: C
options.text: Because beef and dairy production are responsible for over 60% of all food-based emissions, while only providing around 18% of the world's calories

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are the most efficient source of protein

options.label: D

options.label: C
options.text: Member of the youth group council

options.label: D
options.text: Advisor to the NAACP national office

multiple-choice.question: What was Rosa Parks' occupation by day, and what was she doing by night?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: By day, she was a seamstress, and by night, she was researching and documenting civil rights cases

options.label: C
options.text: By day, she was a lawyer, and by night, she was a activist

options.label: D
options.text: By day, she was an activist, and by night, she was a seamstress

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the Montgomery Bus Boycott in 1956?

options.label: A
options.text: The Supreme Court ruled in favor of desegregating public transport, but Rosa Parks was arrested and jailed for her one-woman protest

options.label: B
options.text: The Supreme Court ruled against desegregating public transport, and Rosa Parks was unable to find work in Montgomery

options.label: C
options.text: The Montgomery Bus Boycott ended in failure, and Rosa Parks was forced to move to Detroit

options.label: D
options.text: The Montgomery Bus Boycott ended in favor of desegregating public transport, and Rosa Parks was hailed as a hero

options.label: A
options.text: She was forced to move due to the backlash from the Montgomery Bus Boycott

options.label: B
options.text: She was unable to find work in Montgomery because of her political reputation

options.label: C
options.text: She wanted to start a new chapter in her life and leave the activism behind

options.label: D
options.text: She was offered a job by Congressman John Conyers to help support his burgeoning civil rights campaigns

title: The wicked wit of Jane Austen - Iseult Gillespie

multiple-choice.question: What is a unique feature of Jane Austen's writing style?

options.label: B
options.text: She incorporates elements of science fiction.

options.label: C
options.text: She uses a dry wit and cheeky playfulness to inform her heroines.

options.label: D
options.text: She rarely uses dialogue in her novels.

multiple-choice.question: What is a common thread in Jane Austen's work?

options.label: A
options.text: Sweeping romance is the primary focus of her novels.

options.label: B
options.text: Romance is a common thread, but Austen explores the tension between romantic love and economic necessity.

options.label: C
options.text: Austen's novels primarily focus on the lives of men in rural England.

options.label: D
options.text: Austen's novels are largely devoid of romantic themes.

multiple-choice.question: Why did Jane Austen's novels often explore the tension between romantic love and economic necessity?

options.label: A
options.text: Because she was born into a wealthy family and did not have to worry about financial stability.

options.label: B
options.text: Because she never married and therefore understood the importance of economic security for women.

options.label: C
options.text: Because she lived in a society where a wealthy marriage was a financial necessity for most young women.

options.label: D
options.text: Because she was opposed to the idea of women marrying for financial security.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of Jane Austen's characters?

options.label: A
options.text: They are often passive and lacking in agency.

options.label: B
options.text: They are often intelligent women with witty, pragmatic personalities and rich inner lives.

options.label: C
options.text: They are often one-dimensional and lack complexity.

options.label: D
options.text: They are often villainous and devoid of redeeming qualities.

multiple-choice.question: What is a characteristic of Austen's heroines that is often used to their disadvantage?

options.label: A
options.text: Their intelligence and wit often lead them to make poor decisions.

options.label: B
options.text: Their strong sense of independence often leads them to reject romantic offers.

options.label: C
options.text: Their tendency to think they have all the answers often blinds them to their own flaws and biases.

options.label: D
options.text: Their lack of emotional depth often makes them unsympathetic to readers.
